Award.AwardTitle: NSF INCLUDES DDLP American STEM Alliance Network Improvement Community
Award.AbstractNarration:
The NSF INCLUDES Design and Development Launch Pilot: American STEM Alliance Network Improvement Community focuses on the broadening participation challenge of providing equitable access to STEM education in high-need, majority Hispanic and Native American communities. The project will apply both collective impact and network improvement community collaborative change strategies in their effort with three school districts in the Southwest serving majority Hispanic and Native American communities (San Antonio, TX, Farmington, NM, and Andarko, OK). The proposed model of collaborative change for this project combines the stakeholder engagement focus of collective impact with the strategic, iterative improvement emphasis of the networked improvement community approaches. The American Institutes of Research (AIR) and the American STEM Alliance (ASA) provide leadership for this effort. A key feature of this project is that it brings new ways of community engagement, data driven decision making, and institutional collaboration to an existing Alliance with an established reputation with the target population. The rapid cycle study design proposed by this project will contribute to understanding how communities can develop stronger, more evidence based approaches to addressing the grand challenge of broadening participation across a variety of contexts.

The goal of this project is to develop and test a contextually, and culturally relevant approach to addressing inequities in STEM education. The project proposes to promote equitable access to a coherent continuum of support in STEM education pathways. The Carnegie STEM Excellence Pathway provides the tools and resources for the participating districts to identify a problem of practice and create an intervention to address that problem using a data-driven framework, proven tools/techniques, and continuous feedback. The project evaluation focuses on documenting the collaborative change strategies, continuous improvement cycles, and their contribution to the changes in institutional policy and practice required to create increased access to rigorous STEM courses for Hispanic and Native American high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The "NSF INCLUDES American STEM Alliance Networked Improvement Community" project aimed to develop partnerships among organizations to design, pilot, and test STEM education interventions, with the goal of improving equitable access to rigorous and diverse STEM pathways. The project was funded as a Design and Development Launch Pilot (DDLP) with American Institutes for Research (AIR) serving as the backbone organization. Additionally, Dr. Raul (Rudy) Reyna, of the American STEM Alliance, served as project consultant.

For the project, AIR worked with district, school, and community members from Southwest Independent School District (San Antonio, Texas) and Anadarko Public Schools (Anadarko, Oklahoma). The project team had also hoped to collaborate with Navaho Preparatory School in Farmington, New Mexico, but various challenges proved insurmountable.

Although Southwest ISD and Anadarko Public Schools are located in different states and community types, they encounter similar academic, socioemotional, and sociocultural biases and barriers that affect student participation and persistence in STEM pathways. These communities serve students traditionally underrepresented in STEM fields. At Southwest ISD, Hispanic students comprise 91% of the student body. Native American students represent 44.9% of students in Anadarko Public Schools. These groups participate and persist at low rates in STEM academic and career pathways. There is concern that U.S. schools are not adequately engaging and promoting Hispanic student success in STEM, and schools continue to struggle to meet the STEM needs of American Indian students.

Guided by this context, goals of the funded project have been to (1) support each site in developing and implementing a plan designed to increase the participation (and success) of historically under-represented populations in STEM courses and ultimately careers, and (2) equip the sites to sustain their STEM efforts after the current grant has been completed.

The main activities carried out in support of these goals fall under four domains: (1) community-based partnership or advisory team meetings, (2) AIR and Dr. Reyna planning with site leaders, (3) developing and sharing of an overview of the collective impact approach, and (4) developing and sharing an archive of potential funding and information sources for ongoing efforts.

With Southwest ISD, these four domains were pursued as project partners convened the district’s community-based STEM partners under the auspices of the Career and Technical Education (CTE) advisory group to conduct collaborative planning. Meeting three times per year, this CTE advisory group focused on developing a strong STEM pipeline from elementary through high school and beyond. AIR and Dr. Reyna helped the district with accountability and monitoring of progress toward STEM goals. Through a series of check-in meetings and consultations, AIR and Dr. Reyna helped Southwest ISD establish checkpoints and stay on-track regarding recruitment of additional members for CTE advisory meetings and identifying resources to enhance professional development of educators.

With Anadarko Public Schools, an interesting and ultimately powerful change of strategy occurred during the life of the grant. As Year 2 began, the project’s primary contact from Anadarko Public Schools recognized and articulated that the previous focus on Project-Based Learning (or Problem-Based Learning) was not gaining traction with the district and was perceived by some administrators as incongruent with school site plans. As a result, project focus shifted to developing sustainable relationships in the broader community in order to support and develop effective STEM programs. What was initially envisioned as a small advisory group to serve this purpose grew substantially during the life of the grant. The resulting alliance – Southwest Oklahoma STEM Alliance (SOSA) – grew from 17 to over 45 members, representing five tribes, four community organizations, three school districts, and nine industry partners.

SOSA’s stated purpose is to provide interdisciplinary curricula, state- and nation-wide collaborations, and peer mentorship that provide pathways not only for career success but also student well-being and lifelong learning.

Regarding results, the project’s external evaluation documented the following:

For Southwest ISD, project activities motivated the district to monitor and assess their progress on STEM initiatives in new and improved ways. AIR also supported the district with accessing STEM-related resources and facilitating connections with new partners. Two district leaders are quoted in the external evaluation report, specifying the ways the INCLUDES grant helped the district track progress on goals, accelerate efforts to recruit additional partners for CTE advisory meetings, and bring core STEM opportunities to the district.

For Anadarko and SOSA, project team activities are given much credit by SOSA’s members for giving structure to the very creation of the alliance. The project team supported SOSA in creating workgroups – identifying members and creating objectives and activities for each. Further, the project team supported SOSA’s development by co-facilitating meetings, providing feedback, sharing information and resources, and serving as a thought partner. Resources shared with SOSA included a briefing and slide-deck on the collective impact paradigm – suitable for sharing with alliance members internally and with community members more broadly.
